articles.headline: This Is the Guy Who’s Taking Away the Likes
articles.snippet: Adam Mosseri, chieftain of Instagram, wants to keep the platform a safe, special space. That means learning from the mistakes of its parent company: Facebook.
articles.abstract: Adam Mosseri, chieftain of Instagram, wants to keep the platform a safe, special space. That means learning from the mistakes of its parent company: Facebook.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, Adam Mosseri, the head of Instagram, assembled members of his staff to discuss the secret details of a critical project: the elimination of public “likes.” You’ll be able to see how many hearts your posts get, dear user, but not other people’s tallies. The effort is referred to internally as “Project Daisy” — as in “Does she love me? Or love me not?”

articles.headline: Panicking About Your Kids’ Phones? New Research Says Don’t
articles.snippet: A growing number of academics are challenging assumptions about the negative effects of social media and smartphones on children.
articles.abstract: A growing number of academics are challenging assumptions about the negative effects of social media and smartphones on children.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It has become common wisdom that too much time spent on smartphones and social media is responsible for a recent spike in anxiety, depression and other mental health problems, especially among teenagers.

articles.headline: Federal Workers Profit From Tobacco and Oil, Even If They Don’t Want To
articles.snippet: The Thrift Savings Plan for retirement savings mirrors index funds that invest in such stocks. There’s a fix.
articles.abstract: The Thrift Savings Plan for retirement savings mirrors index funds that invest in such stocks. There’s a fix.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many people who work for the Office of the Surgeon General have exposure to tobacco stocks. At the Environmental Protection Agency, scientists make money when polluters do well. And Justice Department lawyers who keep weapons off the streets stake some of their net worth on retailers that sell guns.

articles.headline: Trump Targets Michelle Obama’s School Nutrition Guidelines on Her Birthday
articles.snippet: The Agriculture Department proposed a rule that would further unravel nutrition standards set by Mrs. Obama when she was first lady.
articles.abstract: The Agriculture Department proposed a rule that would further unravel nutrition standards set by Mrs. Obama when she was first lady.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration moved on Friday to roll back school nutrition standards championed by Michelle Obama, an effort long sought by food manufacturers and some school districts that have chafed at the cost of Mrs. Obama’s prescriptions for fresh fruit and vegetables.

articles.headline: Why Electing a Female President Is Secondary for Some Women
articles.snippet: In the Trump era, some voters say the power of a symbolic first is overshadowed by anxiety about defeating him.
articles.abstract: In the Trump era, some voters say the power of a symbolic first is overshadowed by anxiety about defeating him.
articles.lead_paragraph: WINTERSET, Iowa — Almost exactly three years ago, Leila Schlenker marveled at the crowds at the Women’s March in Des Moines, which drew more than 26,000 people to the grounds of the state capitol and reminded her of the large social protests of the 1960s.

articles.headline: Please Stop Big Tech, Small Rivals Tell Lawmakers
articles.snippet: Until Friday, few executives had complained in public about how Google, Apple, Amazon and Facebook hurt their businesses.
articles.abstract: Until Friday, few executives had complained in public about how Google, Apple, Amazon and Facebook hurt their businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: For all the criticisms directed at the largest tech companies in the last couple of years, few smaller rivals have been willing to speak up publicly.

articles.headline: As Libya Descends Into Chaos, Foreign Powers Look for a Way Out
articles.snippet: A meeting in Berlin on Sunday will seek an exit to one of the Middle East’s most intractable proxy wars.
articles.abstract: A meeting in Berlin on Sunday will seek an exit to one of the Middle East’s most intractable proxy wars.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — Russia has sent hundreds of mercenaries to back militias laying siege to Libya’s capital. The United Arab Emirates has sent jets and drones, while Egypt has provided logistical support.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Declan Walsh

articles.headline: The Secretive Company That Might End Privacy as We Know It
articles.snippet: A little-known start-up helps law enforcement match photos of unknown people to their online images — and “might lead to a dystopian future or something,” a backer says.
articles.abstract: A little-known start-up helps law enforcement match photos of unknown people to their online images — and “might lead to a dystopian future or something,” a backer says.
articles.lead_paragraph: Until recently, Hoan Ton-That’s greatest hits included an obscure iPhone game and an app that let people put Donald Trump’s distinctive yellow hair on their own photos.

articles.headline: Impeachment Trial Puts Susan Collins, Stung by Kavanaugh Backlash, Under Scrutiny
articles.snippet: The four-term Maine senator, who crossed party lines to vote against President Clinton’s impeachment, must now decide whether to break with President Trump.
articles.abstract: The four-term Maine senator, who crossed party lines to vote against President Clinton’s impeachment, must now decide whether to break with President Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A few days after Senator Susan Collins cast her votes to acquit President Bill Clinton, as she was greeted with icy stares at a Lincoln Day dinner in rural Maine, a fellow Republican approached her, irate.

articles.headline: Harry and Meghan Give Up Royal Titles and Forgo State Funding
articles.snippet: An agreement represents one of the most dramatic ruptures within the British royal family since King Edward VIII abdicated the throne in 1936 to marry an American woman, Wallis Simpson.
articles.abstract: An agreement represents one of the most dramatic ruptures within the British royal family since King Edward VIII abdicated the throne in 1936 to marry an American woman, Wallis Simpson.
articles.lead_paragraph: WINDSOR, England — Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, will stop using their loftiest royal titles, give up state funding and repay at least $3 million in taxpayer money used to refurbish their official residence at Windsor Castle under an agreement announced by Buckingham Palace on Saturday.

articles.headline: Trump’s Defense Team Calls Impeachment Charges ‘Brazen’ as Democrats Make Legal Case
articles.snippet: In a six-page filing formally responding to the impeachment charges, President Trump’s lawyers rejected the case against him as illegitimate and described the effort to remove him as dangerous.
articles.abstract: In a six-page filing formally responding to the impeachment charges, President Trump’s lawyers rejected the case against him as illegitimate and described the effort to remove him as dangerous.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s legal defense team strenuously denied on Saturday that he had committed impeachable acts, denouncing the charges against him as a “brazen and unlawful” attempt to cost him re-election as House Democrats laid out in meticulous detail their case that he should be removed from office.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: These Syrian Women Rarely Left the House. Then the Men Disappeared.
articles.snippet: In parts of Syria, women once stepped out of their homes only rarely — at least until war came. Now some are relishing a newfound independence.
articles.abstract: In parts of Syria, women once stepped out of their homes only rarely — at least until war came. Now some are relishing a newfound independence.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALEPPO, Syria — The women of eastern Aleppo were rarely visible before the war, but now they shape the bitter peace. In the poor, conservative districts of Syria’s ancient commercial capital, many women seldom used to leave the house, and only with their husbands if they did; the men not only won the bread, but also went out to buy it.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee and Hwaida Saad

articles.headline: How 17 Outsize Portraits Rattled a Small Southern Town
articles.snippet: Newnan, Ga., decided to use art to help the community celebrate diversity and embrace change. Not everyone was ready for what they saw.
articles.abstract: Newnan, Ga., decided to use art to help the community celebrate diversity and embrace change. Not everyone was ready for what they saw.
articles.lead_paragraph: [To read more provocative stories on race from The New York Times, sign up for our Race/Related newsletter here.]

articles.headline: Even C-SPAN Is Piqued: Senate Puts Limits on Trial Coverage
articles.snippet: The Senate will control the cameras during the impeachment trial, limiting what viewers see, and reporters will be confined to roped-off areas.
articles.abstract: The Senate will control the cameras during the impeachment trial, limiting what viewers see, and reporters will be confined to roped-off areas.
articles.lead_paragraph: News coverage of President Trump’s impeachment trial in the Senate began last week with a Republican senator calling a CNN reporter “a liberal hack” in the halls of Congress and laughing about it later that night during a Fox News interview.

articles.headline: How U.S. Firms Helped Africa’s Richest Woman Exploit Her Country’s Wealth
articles.snippet: Isabel dos Santos, the daughter of Angola’s former president, built an empire in a country mired in corruption. Western consultants were her advisers.
articles.abstract: Isabel dos Santos, the daughter of Angola’s former president, built an empire in a country mired in corruption. Western consultants were her advisers.
articles.lead_paragraph: LISBON — [Update: Isabel dos Santos is set to face embezzlement charges in Angola.]
articles.byline: By Michael Forsythe, Kyra Gurney, Scilla Alecci and Ben Hallman

articles.headline: Where Is Cory Gardner?
articles.snippet: As the Senate impeachment trial of President Trump nears, the Republican senator from Colorado has gone to ground as he tries to keep moderates and independents in his corner while facing a tough re-election race.
articles.abstract: As the Senate impeachment trial of President Trump nears, the Republican senator from Colorado has gone to ground as he tries to keep moderates and independents in his corner while facing a tough re-election race.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — They keep expecting to see Senator Cory Gardner everywhere — on the local Fox affiliates in Colorado, on Facebook, on literature crammed inside their mailboxes. They are voters who wear tasteful crepe blouses and carry structured Kate Spade totes, who like how their 401(k)’s are performing but say they could do without President Trump’s “temperament.”

articles.headline: The Big Ask of Black Voters: Trust the Government
articles.snippet: Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren and Pete Buttigieg are trying to woo older black voters with policy. Those policies may be why they’re struggling to win their support.
articles.abstract: Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren and Pete Buttigieg are trying to woo older black voters with policy. Those policies may be why they’re struggling to win their support.
articles.lead_paragraph: DANVILLE, Va. — Ten minutes into a small community meeting between black farmers from Southern Virginia and regional campaign staff for Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, an aide took the floor.

articles.headline: Democrats Seek More Testimony and Evidence for Impeachment Trial
articles.snippet: Even as the Senate prepares for the substantive start of the proceedings against President Trump, there are big unanswered questions. Here are some of them.
articles.abstract: Even as the Senate prepares for the substantive start of the proceedings against President Trump, there are big unanswered questions. Here are some of them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With President Trump’s impeachment trial getting underway, Democrats are intensifying their demands for more testimony and documents that could add to the already voluminous evidence against him and bolster their case by shedding new light on several key questions.

articles.headline: A New Player at Sundance, Backed by Laurene Powell Jobs
articles.snippet: One-fourth of the documentaries in the Sundance Film Festival’s competition for American nonfiction films come from the same upstart company, Concordia Studio.
articles.abstract: One-fourth of the documentaries in the Sundance Film Festival’s competition for American nonfiction films come from the same upstart company, Concordia Studio.
articles.lead_paragraph: The coming out party will feature teenagers from Texas, journalists from Manila and a woman in Louisiana who spent 21 years fighting to free her husband from prison.

articles.headline: Rural Montana Had Already Lost Too Many Native Women. Then Selena Disappeared.
articles.snippet: For decades, with little public notice, Native women have gone missing or been found murdered. The search for Selena Not Afraid showed how much things had changed.
articles.abstract: For decades, with little public notice, Native women have gone missing or been found murdered. The search for Selena Not Afraid showed how much things had changed.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIG HORN COUNTY, Mont. — Jackie Big Hair slept in her car for days, waking every few hours to fire up the engine and gaze at the frozen highway rest stop where her 16-year-old daughter had been reported missing.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Cristina Baussan

articles.headline: Amid Tight Security, Virginia Gun Rally Draws Thousands of Supporters
articles.snippet: Some 22,000 people, many of them armed, flooded the streets around the State Capitol to protest gun control proposals from the new Democratic majority.
articles.abstract: Some 22,000 people, many of them armed, flooded the streets around the State Capitol to protest gun control proposals from the new Democratic majority.
articles.lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — Some people streamed in on buses from faraway cities. Others drove cars through the night from places like Indianapolis and Fredericksburg, Texas, logging hundreds of miles and leaning on coffee and Red Bull. Still others came from only a few counties over, but carrying the same vehement message as the rest: Leave gun laws alone.
articles.byline: By Timothy Williams, Sabrina Tavernise, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Sarah Mervosh

articles.headline: Trump’s China Deal Creates Collateral Damage for Tech Firms
articles.snippet: Micron secured some gains from the China deal but it may end up suffering bigger losses from the broader U.S.-China battle.
articles.abstract: Micron secured some gains from the China deal but it may end up suffering bigger losses from the broader U.S.-China battle.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Among the corporate titans recognized last week by President Trump during a White House signing ceremony for his China trade deal was Sanjay Mehrotra, the chief executive of Micron Technology, whose Idaho semiconductor company is at the heart of Mr. Trump’s trade war.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: How Boeing’s Responsibility in a Deadly Crash ‘Got Buried’
articles.snippet: A study that blasted Boeing after a 2009 accident was never made public. Other criticisms were tempered by investigators after the company and U.S. safety officials objected.
articles.abstract: A study that blasted Boeing after a 2009 accident was never made public. Other criticisms were tempered by investigators after the company and U.S. safety officials objected.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a Boeing 737 crashed near Amsterdam more than a decade ago, the Dutch investigators focused blame on the pilots for failing to react properly when an automated system malfunctioned and caused the plane to plummet into a field, killing nine people.
